text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This section has been updated to provide comprehensive guidance that addresses excise tax closings. Content was added to be more cohesive, current and accurate.
The table below identiﬁes the signiﬁcant changes in content.
4.24.21.3.1 20 Day Timeframe for Closing Agreed and/or No Change Cases
Title changed to
Day Timeframe for Closing Agreed and/or No Change Excise Cases. New content incorpo- rated from IGM SB/SE
, Interim Guidance Procedures for frames to Close Agreed and No- Change Examinations, that provides guidance about newly established timeframes for closing agreed and/or no change excise cases.

IRM Section Number Description of Change 4.24.21.4.4 Form 5344 - Ex- Content about Form 5344 linked to amination Closing Record information at the Excise Tax Knowledge Base Home Page. 4.24.21.4.5 Form 5351 - Content about Form 5351 linked to Examined Non-Examination information at the Excise Tax Closings Record Knowledge Base Home Page. 4.24.21.5 Closing Proce- Title changed to Excise Closing Proce- dures by Type of Closure dures by Type of Closure. New content added to provide information about forms, letters and closing procedures for no change excise report non-ﬁled excise return report. dures. New content added to provide information about forms, letters and closing procedures for no change excise report non

formation at the Excise Tax Knowledge Base Home Page.

Title changed to Closing Procedures for Unagreed Excise Examinations Not to be Forwarded to Appeals. mentation. Title changed to Review of Excise Case. Title changed to Grade of Excise

Title changed to Closing Procedures for Unagreed Excise Examinations Not to be Forwarded to Appeals. New content added to provide information about closing procedures for unagreed excise examinations not to be forwarded to Appeals. Additional content linked to information at the Excise Tax Knowledge Base Home Page.
Editorial changes were made throughout this IRM, such as updating electronic hyperlinks and IRM references.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This material supersedes IRM 4.24.21 dated May 12, 2017, and Interim Guidance Memorandum (IGM) SB/SE 04-1018-0036, Interim Guidance Procedures for Timeframes to Close Agreed and No-Change Examinations, dated October 1, 2018.
AUDIENCE
Table of Contents

) General Overview - This IRM provides speciﬁc information and procedural guidance about closing excise examination reports (excise reports) in terms and content and format. A taxpayer has the right to appeal an IRS decision in independent forum, which allows for a fair and impartial administrative (

) Purpose - For compliance purposes, it is essential excise managers, level officials and excise examiners understand and correctly follow the technical guidance and closing processes explained in this IRM section so accurate excise reports result. Executed excise reports, unlike workpapers, legally binding documents and serve as the basis for assessment and tion actions. (
) Audience - This IRM is for excise managers and excise examiners who excise reports. (
) Policy Owner - Director, Examination - Speciality Policy is responsible for administration, procedures and updates related to closing excise reports. (
) Program Owner - Director, Examination - Specialty Examination owns Tax Examination. (

) Primary Stakeholders - Appeals, Agency-Wide Shared Services, Counsel, Specialty Examination, SB/SE Field and Specialty Examination Quality and Large Business and International (LB&I) are the primary stakeholders this IRM. (

) The processes and procedures provided in this IRM are consistent with the objectives or goals for Excise Tax Examination addressed in IRM Organization and Staffing, Small Business and Self/Employed (SB/SE), Tax Examination. (
) IRC

, Content of tax due, deﬁciencies, and other notices, requires notices describe the basis for and identify the amounts of the tax due, additional amounts, additions to tax and assessable penalties included in notice. The notices speciﬁed include the ﬁrst letter of proposed deﬁciency ing a review by Appeals, a notice of deﬁciency and notices of tax due. the statutory requirement is limited to the speciﬁed notices, the conference port notes the Congress desires the Service make every effort to improve clarity of all explanations sent to taxpayers. ) Chief, Estate & Gift/Excise Tax Examination is the executive responsible for ensuring information about closing excise reports is communicated to and carried out by excise managers and excise examiners.
Policy Owner - Director, Examination - Speciality Policy is responsible for administration, procedures and updates related to closing excise reports.
Tax Examination. (
) IRC

, Content of tax due, deﬁciencies, and other notices, requires notices describe the basis for and identify the amounts of the tax due, additional amounts, additions to tax and assessable penalties included in notice. The notices speciﬁed include the ﬁrst letter of proposed deﬁciency ing a review by Appeals, a notice of deﬁciency and notices of tax due. While the statutory requirement is limited to the speciﬁed notices, the conference re- port notes the Congress desires the Service make every effort to improve the clarity of all explanations sent to taxpayers. ) Director, Examination - Specialty Policy is the executive responsible for Tax Examination policy and procedures. (
) Director, Examination - Specialty Examination is the executive responsible for examination operational compliance. (

) Chief, Estate & Gift/Excise Tax Examination is the executive responsible for ensuring information about closing excise reports is communicated to and carried out by excise managers and excise examiners.
) Program Goals - The processes and procedures provided in this IRM are sistent with the objectives or goals for Excise Tax Examination addressed in Objectives and IRM

) Program Reports - Information regarding the reporting of program are included on, but not limited to Headquarters Examination Monthly Program Manager Monthly Brieﬁng, Examination Operational Review and Business Performance Reviews, which are provided to Director, Examination Specialty Policy. (

) Program Effectiveness - Program effectiveness is measured by the tion Quality Review Staff, located in FSEQ, that supports the SB/SE quality improvement program utilizing National Quality Review System (NQRS) to conduct independent case reviews from a statistically valid sample of tion case work. National, area and territory trend analysis for the quality attributes establish baselines to assess program performance, identify nities to improve work processes, analyze causes for failure, assess the feasibility of possible solutions and measure the success of quality improve- ment efforts. (
) Annual Review - Program Manager, Excise Tax Policy is responsible for reviewing information in this IRM annually to ensure accuracy and promote consistent tax administration. (

) The following chart contains terms and their deﬁnitions used throughout this IRM. Term Deﬁnition AMDISA Command Code (CC) so, if the modifer “A” is added to CC AMDIS and input with the Tax Identiﬁ- cation Number (TIN), File Source, Master File Tax (MFT) (or Plan Number) and Tax Period, up to seven screens will be displayed. BMFOLI CC to request on/off line status of entity and tax modules. BMFOLR CC to request Business Master File (BMF) return screen information. BMFOLT CC to request BMF tax module screen information.

) IRS formally adopted a Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) in June
, which provides the nation’s taxpayers with a better understanding of their rights helps reinforce the fairness of the tax system. In
, Congress charged Commissioner with ensuring IRS employees are familiar with and act in dance with taxpayer rights as afforded by IRC

), Execution of in accordance with taxpayer rights. IRS employees must be informed about taxpayer rights and be conscientious in the performance of their duties to honor, respect and communicate effectively those rights that may aid in ing taxpayer burdens. IRS employees must administer the law with integrity and fairness and exercise professional judgment in conducting enforcement activities. Refer to Pub
, Your Rights as a Taxpayer, for more information.
to IRM 4.24.2, Form 637 Excise Tax Registrations, for information Form 637 registration program compliance cases.
Refer to IRM 4.24.8, Examination Guidance for Excise Claims for Refund or Abatement, for information about closing excise claim cases.
All excise tax ﬁeld groups (excise groups) should send excise reports on agreed, no change and surveyed excise tax cases (excise cases) to Cincinnati Centralized Case Processing (CCP) via Form
, Document Transmittal.
Note: If a taxpayer failed to timely respond to a Letter

Day Letter - Straight Deﬁciency or Overassessment for Excise Tax Examination Cases, or otherwise failed to satisfy the requirements for a review of case ﬁndings by Appeals, that case should be sent to CCP via Form
Refer to IRM
, Appeals Referral Procedures, Appeals Referral Process, for further guidance.

) Taking timely actions on an excise case is an essential element for the examination cycle time and is key to taxpayer satisfaction. Nationally Case Closing mandated timeframes dictate when the excise examiner should initiate, follow-up or complete certain actions. (

) The current time frames for case action may be found at IRM Exhibit General Examining Procedures, Guidelines for SB/SE National Quality NQRS Time Frames for Case Action. Speciﬁc excise case closing are indicated below. (
) NQRS reviews, agreed or no change examinations are to be closed in

calendar days measured from the date the agreed report is received or the Day Timeframe for date the no change status is communicated to the taxpayer to the date the Agreed and/or case is closed from the excise group and updated in Examination Return Change Excise Control System (ERCS). (
) Examination Quality Review System (EQRS) reviews, agreed and no examinations are to be closed within
calendar days. The
days are divided as follows: a. The excise examiner has
days to close agreed and no change examinations to the excise manager. The
day period begins on the earlier of the date the agreed report is received from the taxpayer or date the no change status is communicated to the taxpayer. The
period ends on the day the case is mailed to the excise manager the IMS case ﬁle is updated for closing. b. The excise manager has
days to close agreed and no change examinations from the excise group. The
day period is measured the date the case is mailed to the excise manager or the IMS case ﬁle updated to the excise manager to the date the case is updated to status on ERCS. (
) The timeframe is calculated beginning the day immediately following the rence of one of the events described immediately above. (
) Delays in meeting the timeframe must be documented on Form

, Examining Officer’s Activity Record, by the excise examiner and/or excise manager. The excise manager may utilize whatever features are available in IMS to make comments (e.g., Case Comments via the time sheet on a

or Case Level Activities at the Team Web Site). Documentation must explain the facts and circumstances that caused the delay. Timeframes may extended whenever documentation establishes the excise examiner and/or excise manager exercised ordinary care and prudence. (
) Currently, excise taxes subject to the provisions for unpaid deﬁciencies of $

and greater are administered by Tax Exempt/Governmental for Closing not Excise Tax Examination. Excise Cases Note: The unpaid deﬁciency applies per tax period not the aggregate amount. Unpaid Deﬁciencies $
and Greater (
) The only excise taxes subject to these procedures are under Chapters

days to close agreed and no change excise examinations to the excise manager. The
day period begins on the earlier of the date the agreed report is received from the taxpayer or the date the no change status is communicated to the taxpayer. The
day period ends on the day the case is mailed to the excise manager and/or the IMS case ﬁle is updated for closing. b. The excise manager has
days to close agreed and no change excise examinations from the excise group. The
day period is measured from the date the case is mailed to the excise manager or the IMS case ﬁle is updated to the excise manager to the date the case is updated to closing status on ERCS.
The timeframe is calculated beginning the day immediately following the occur- rence of one of the events described immediately above.

) The excise examiner and excise manager have
calendar days to close unagreed excise case measured from the earlier of: • The date to respond to Letter
-E. • The date the request for an Appeals conference is received from the taxpayer to the date the excise case is forwarded to Technical (Tech Services). (
) The timeframe is calculated beginning the day immediately following the rence of one of the events described immediately above. (
) Delays in meeting the timeframe must be documented on Form

by the excise examiner and/or excise manager. The excise manager may utilize whatever features are available in Issue Management System (IMS) to comments (e.g., Case Comments via the time sheet on a Form

or Level Activities at the Team Web Site). Documentation must explain the and circumstances that caused the delay. Timeframes may be extended whenever documentation establishes the excise examiner and/or excise manager exercised ordinary care and prudence. (
) Once the excise examiner issues the report, the excise case must be for closing. (
) The following topics address the general steps to prepare the excise case gardless of the type of closing. (
) The excise case closing process requires a paper ﬁle closing and a IMS closing. The excise examiner will attempt to close both IMS and paper ﬁles at the same time. (

) The excise examiner will include all key documents in the IMS ﬁle. The examiner will also print and organize all key documents into the paper ﬁle, which will be mailed to the excise manager for further processing. Key documents will include, but are not limited to, work papers or supporting mentation (or portions thereof) detailing all proposed adjustments. Effort be made by the excise examiner to index all key documents in the IMS ﬁle similar fashion to those in the paper ﬁle. The excise examiner should apply judgment as to what information is necessary to include in both IMS and ﬁles. The excise manager’s advice should be sought, if any question exists to whether the document should be included. (

) The excise manager will review the closed excise case upon receipt. of the excise case will include a comparison by the excise manager of the paper ﬁle to the IMS ﬁle. If any inconsistencies exist, the excise manager return the excise case ﬁle to the excise examiner for correction. The excise manager will document all closing actions in IMS on Form

, Examining Officer’s Activity Record, or through Case Level Activities at the IMS Team Web Site. If the excise manager added or changed any documents, those documents must be uploaded or saved in the IMS ﬁle and printed for the ﬁle. (
) The status of the IMS ﬁle must be updated to “closed” by the excise but not until it reaches on the Examination Return Controls System (ERCS) either Status
or Status
, which is determined as to when by the excise manager. The excise manager must then complete the managerial actions Internal Revenue Manual
The timeframe is calculated beginning the day immediately following the occur- rence of one of the events described immediately above.
Delays in meeting the timeframe must be documented on Form

by the excise examiner and/or excise manager. The excise manager may utilize whatever features are available in Issue Management System (IMS) to make comments (e.g., Case Comments via the time sheet on a Form

or Case Level Activities at the Team Web Site). Documentation must explain the facts and circumstances that caused the delay. Timeframes may be extended whenever documentation establishes the excise examiner and/or excise manager exercised ordinary care and prudence.

) The excise examiner should verify the correct statute of limitations (SOL) period for assessment of tax date is reﬂected on all transcripts. Transcripts IDRS must be less than
days old but preferably less than one week old. (

For example, the Failure to File, Failure to Pay and Failure to Deposit penalties are individually entered in IMS as IRC 6651(a)(1), Failure to ﬁle tax return or pay tax, Addition to the tax, IRC 6651 (a)(2), Failure to ﬁle tax re- turn or pay tax, Addition to the tax, and IRC 6656 Failure to make deposit of taxes. These penalties are then listed separately on Form 3198 when gener- ated in IMS. Additionally, if no penalties are asserted, IMS allows the excise examiner to report zero for penalty non-assertion.

) The excise examiner is responsible to select those forms and letters that to the taxpayer’s situation. During the course of the examination, the examiner must selectively issue forms and letters directly to the taxpayer selectively forward letters to CCP to be issued to the taxpayer when the case fully closes. The excise examiner is responsible to select those forms and letters that apply to the taxpayer’s situation. During the course of the examination, the excise examiner must selectively issue forms and letters directly to the taxpayer and selectively forward letters to CCP to be issued to the taxpayer when the excise case fully closes. The excise examiner must complete those forms and letters that are not automatically populated, as well as review and correct them for accuracy.

) To support the decision to survey the return after assignment, the excise examiner must ensure the case ﬁle has been documented with all actions taken, which led to this conclusion, including, but not be limited to, ation of Large, Unusual or Questionable items, completion of required ﬁling checks, consideration of collectibility, evaluation of audit potential, repetitive audits and other materials that inﬂuenced his or her decision. days or more. For this reason, the excise examiner may decide to request examination controls on a later period to be more current. Letter 4121-X, Letter to Transmit Expected Agreed Examination Report, must be issued on an agreed case when the taxpayer indicated probable agreement with the proposed examination changes. When a taxpayer does not respond to Letter 4121-X within the requested time frame, the excise examiner should follow up with the taxpayer to determine if unagreed case procedures should be initiated. , Non-Filer No Liability Substitute for Return (SFR) Transmittal Procedures for No Liability SFR Non-Filer Examinations: a. The excise examiner must prepare an original and a copy of Letter advising the taxpayer there is no liability for the excise tax indicated, well as an envelope addressed to the taxpayer. b. Letter
will be signed by the excise manager on behalf of the Estate and Gift/Excise Tax Examination. c. Both copies of Letter
and the addressed envelope will be placed the paper ﬁle. d. The excise examiner will note under the Letter Instructions for the section on Form
“Other Instructions” box, “No Liability SFR - Letter
to the taxpayer.” e. CCP ensures the original letter is mailed to the taxpayer and the copy remains in the paper ﬁle. (

) IMS Case Closing: a. Established no change IMS excise case closing procedures are for no liability SFR examinations, including all excise case that is in the paper ﬁle. b. Both the IMS ﬁle and the paper ﬁle must contain documentation to support the no liability determination. c. The IMS ﬁle serves as the historical record for all excise examiner actions, ﬁndings and determinations that is essential background, if excise case is subsequently identiﬁed and/or classiﬁed. (
) Case File Assembly Procedures - At a minimum the paper ﬁle, as well as IMS ﬁle, will contain: a. A copy of the BMFOLT for the periods involved that show the TC
posting for the SFR and AMDIS to show the module is fully on AIMS. The excise examiner should also check TXMODA to ensure there are no pending transactions. b. Letter
(two copies) with proper signature and an addressed with current taxpayer address. c. Form
d. Form

and any lead sheets or workpapers. (
) Excise Report - If an SFR examination results in a decision the taxpayer is liable for an excise tax in the tax period examined, no excise report is Letter
is all that is necessary because the taxpayer did not ﬁle an return. (
